intro: Plagiobothrys parvulus, commonly known as the small-flowered sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its small, blue or violet flowers that bloom in the spring. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in coastal or inland areas with well-drained conditions. It has slender stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain the seeds. Plagiobothrys parvulus is often found in disturbed habitats and is considered a rare or endangered species in some regions.
